title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under Subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes a new part titled "Designation for Reduction of Public Debt" with section 6097 outlining the designation process. Every individual with adjusted income tax liability can designate up to 10 percent to reduce public debt when filing their tax return. Adjusted income tax liability refers to the income tax owed. The taxpayer can designate up to 10 percent of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt when filing their tax return. Adjusted income tax liability is the income tax owed, reduced by any designated amount to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. The taxpayer can designate up to 10 percent of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, a Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States to pay off federal government obligations at maturity. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations at maturity. Amounts from the Fund can be used to redeem or buy back obligations, which are then canceled and retired without reissue. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations at maturity. Amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the enactment of this Act. Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new section for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration will occur within 15 days after Congress adjourns, equivalent to the estimated aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This is to reduce public debt obligations. The legislation aims to reduce discretionary spending below set limits and address deficit changes resulting from direct spending legislation. Each account in the United States will be reduced by a calculated dollar amount. The legislation aims to reduce discretionary spending below set limits by reducing each account in the United States by a calculated dollar amount, ensuring permanent reductions in obligational authority. Certain accounts, such as the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance program, are exempt from these reductions. The legislation aims to reduce discretionary spending by cutting certain accounts, exempting the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance program. The FSLIC Resolution Fund, FDIC, Savings Association Insurance Fund, NCUA, credit union share insurance fund, and Resolution Trust Corporation are included in the legislation. Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to require a Department of Treasury report to Congress estimating income tax designated under section 6097. The effective date of the amendments is not subject to the expiration date set forth in section 275(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The amendments made by this section to the Balanced Budget Act do not have an expiration date and will only cease to have effect after a fiscal year with no public debt.
